Hi Petar-

Thanks for the reply. I do not have a (non-HyperNEAT) NEAT package around.
Can you let me know if your NEAT implementation is different than what I
report below?

I am using Jason's HyperNEAT 2.5 package available here:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/software.html

If you download the package, the key file is:
HyperNEAT/NEAT/src/NEAT_GeneticIndividual.cpp

I am attaching it, but I don't know how that works with the yahoo group.

Crossover occurs in this constructor:

    GeneticIndividual::GeneticIndividual(shared_ptr<GeneticIndividual>
parent1,shared_ptr<GeneticIndividual> parent2,bool mate_multipoint_avg)

The following line occurs outside of the loop that goes through each link:

 bool chooseFirstParent = (randomChoice<=parent1->getFitness());
 
Then, inside the loop for each link:

                    if (chooseFirstParent)
                    {
                        addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link1));
                    }
                    else
                    {
                        addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link2));
                    }
 
So, it seems that *all* the links will be grabbed from one parent or the
other. Is that how it works in other versions of NEAT?



Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...




> From: petar_chervenski <petar_chervenski@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Sun, 09 Nov 2008 20:14:32 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?
> 
> Hi Jeff, 
> 
> Well I don't know about the exact implementations of HyperNEAT you are
> using (note that P-NEAT is just NEAT with additive mutations
> disabled), but in principle crossover should choose genes randomly
> from both parents as it builds the offspring genome, the child. In
> HyperNEAT the crossover is different, there you actually do a regular
> NEAT evolution of networks that build other networks based on the
> substrate configuration. That is, you only mate and mutate the CPPNs.
> But in the case you get lots of individuals with equal fitness, I
> guess these individuals are clones. Perhaps the code frequently
> chooses the same individuals for mating? You can try to avoid this by
> introducing a loop in which you try candidates for a "father" that are
> not compatible with the mother, that is, when their compatibility
> distance is 0.00, try again. There is another possibility, simply
> every mutation disturbs the CPPN and therefore the produced network is
> changed in such a magnitude that is has no chance for survival and is
> discarded. Even though there is speciation.
> 
> Peter
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Hello all-
>> 
>> Does crossover do anything in PNEAT and HyperNEAT?
>> 
>> PNEAT:
>> If I am reading the code correctly, during crossover, if the
> substrates are
>> the same (i.e. all links have the same ID), which is always the case
> in
>> P-NEAT, *all* of the link values are taken from either parent1 or
> parent2.
>> Isn't it more normal when crossing over to take some from parent1
> and some
>> from parent2? Why grab all from just one?
>> 
>> This means that in PNEAT crossover does nothing, right? It will
> always grab
>> the substrate of parent1 or the substrate of parent2.  If I track
> parent and
>> offspring fitness, 100% of the time the child has the exact same
> fitness as
>> one of the two parents.
>> 
>> On to HyperNEAT:
>> 
>> I tracked the fitness of each parent and the resulting offspring.
> The odd
>> thing is that the organisms that are crossed only (i.e. they are
> never
>> mutated) have the *exact* same fitness of one of their parents
> 98.88% of the
>> time. In 20 runs, that was only 136 orgs out of 12257 that were
> crossed over
>> and not mutated. That seems wrong, doesn't it? Why would these new
> links
>> have such a small impact? It turns out that this is because nearly
> every
>> time that there is an extra link that gets placed in the child, the
> parent
>> that donated that link is also the parent whose weights are being
> grabbed,
>> meaning that the crossover is only copying the parent (hence the
> same
>> fitness). It seems to me that crossover should be much more
> disruptive, no?
>> 
>> 
>> As a final test, I did a set of hyperneat and pneat runs with the
> default
>> 'MutateOnlyProbability' parameter set to .25, so 25% of orgs never
> are
>> candidates for crossover. I then ran experimental treatments
>> hyperneat-noCross and pneat-noCross where the MutateOnlyProbability
>> parameter was set to 1, so no orgs were crossed over. Despite my
> comments
>> above, Hyperneat (with cross) did beat HyperNEAT-noCross, however
> the
>> difference was not tremendous (although it does seem to be
> statistically
>> significant). For p-neat, the reverse was true. Nevertheless, this
> is not a
>> perfect test of whether crossover pays dividends, because if
> crossover does
>> nothing most of the time, and I increase MutateOnlyProbability from
> .25 to
>> 1, I have effectively raised the mutation rate (only 80% of crossed
> orgs are
>> also mutated).
>> 
>> Are these the intended consequences of crossover, or am I missing
> something?
>> 
>> Cheers,
>> Jeff Clune
>> 
>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
>> 
>> jclune@...
>> 
> 
> 
> 


--B_3309092666_14454309
